heading: stock markets ready for y2k
subheading: the national association of securities dealers says a month-long simulation of trading a few days before and after 1 january 2000 turned up no glitches. the financial markets are ready for y2k. by joe nickell.
author: joe ashbrook nickell
text: the national association of securities dealers -- the folks who run nasdaq, the second-largest stock exchange in the world -- said the american financial markets are ready for y2k. over the course of the past month, employees at nasdaq, the american stock exchange, the new york stock exchange, and traders at 144 private financial firms spent their weekends running a simulation of trading a few days before and after 1 january 2000.testers executed more than 170,000 simulated trades of equities, unit investment trusts, mutual funds, corporate bonds, municipal bonds, and money market funds."it feels great to be at this point finally," said gregor bailar, executive vice president and chief information officer of the nasd.despite all the activity, "it was surprisingly uneventful," said bailar. "there were no trading-related glitches. all we found were typical set-up problems for simulating a day you're not living."to get ready for the momentous event, the nasd spent us$55 million and rewrote 11 million lines of code in 300 applications over the past three years.
